title: The Influence of Chromium Thermal-Diffusion-Based Doping on the Spatial Distribution of Luminescence Intensity in ZnSe
summary: This paper investigates the effects of chromium thermal-diffusion-based doping on the spatial distribution of luminescence intensity in ZnSe crystals. The study finds that the doping process leads to the formation of at least two types of defective-impurity centers, which are associated with green and yellow bands. However, machine learning or artificial intelligence methods are not used in this research.

title: A simple Cherenkov detector for educational purposes
summary: This paper presents a low-cost, educational Cherenkov detector constructed from a plastic trash bin and a photo multiplier tube. The detector is used to observe cosmic rays and demonstrates the principle of Cherenkov radiation.

title: Predicting electron spin decoherence with a many-body first-principles approach
summary: This paper presents a many-body theory of spin relaxation and develops precise ab initio calculations of phonon-induced spin decoherence in semiconductors. The authors use a formalism that unifies the modeling of two main sources of phonon-induced spin decoherence, enabling accurate predictions of spin relaxation and precession in semiconductors.
statisticalMethods: The authors use statistical methods, including the Kubo formula and the ladder vertex correction, to calculate the spin relaxation times and precession rates.

title: Dynamical Phase Transition from Nonequilibrium Dynamics of Dark Solitons
summary: This paper discusses a novel dynamical phase transition for superfluids, where the authors identify a critical temperature above which the system relaxes to equilibrium by producing sound waves. The research focuses on the non-equilibrium dynamics of dark solitons and their decay mechanisms, with implications for understanding the behavior of superfluids in various regimes.

title: A Miniature Fabry Perot Sensor for Twist/Rotation, Strain and Temperature Measurements Based on a Four-Core Fiber
summary: This paper presents a novel miniature Fabry-Perot twist/rotation sensor using a four-core fiber and quadruple interferometer setup. The sensor is designed to measure twist/rotation, strain, and temperature with high sensitivity and compactness.

title: Electricity Stealing Time Recognition Method Based on Difference and K-means Clustering
summary: This paper proposes a method to determine the time of electricity stealing by combining difference algorithm and K-means clustering. The method is based on the fluctuation rate of electric quantity, which helps choose a suitable algorithm. For users with low fluctuation rates, the difference algorithm is used, while for those with high fluctuation rates, K-means clustering is employed.

title: Holographic CBK Relation
summary: This paper studies the non-perturbative terms in the Crewther-Broadhurst-Kataev (CBK) relation using a holographic dual theory. The authors derive an exact holographic expression for the Bjorken function and the three-point axial-vector-vector correlation function, showing that they agree with the one-loop expressions obtained in conformal field theories.

title: Magnetic Skyrmions in FePt Square-Based Nanoparticles Around Room-Temperature
summary: This paper studies the formation of magnetic skyrmions around room-temperature in square-based parallelepiped magnetic FePt nanoparticles using micromagnetic simulations. The research focuses on understanding how the confined nature of geometry affects skyrmion creation-stabilization and their size and energetics.

title: Recommended high performance telescope system design for the TianQin project
summary: This paper presents a high-performance telescope system design for the TianQin project, focusing on ultra-stable structure and ultra-low wavefront distortion. The design meets the noise budget requirements for space-based GW detection and can be a good candidate for the TianQin project.

title: A comprehensive study of Modulation effects on CMB Polarization
summary: This paper investigates the effects of modulation on Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) polarization, providing a mathematical explanation for the null result observed in previous studies. The authors show that E mode permits no modulation in general and dipole modulation in particular, with implications for masking and power leakage.

title: Resolve partially the inner disk for Epsilon Eridani
summary: This paper presents mid-infrared imaging observations of the debris disk around Epsilon Eridani, resolving the dust emission in the inner region. The study uses a high angular resolution technique at Mid-Infrared wavelength to investigate the exozodiacal dust of the inner debris disk.

title: Formation of a Quasar Host Galaxy through a Wet Merger
summary: This paper presents high-resolution observations of the molecular gas in the host galaxy of the quasar BRI 1335-0417, located 1.4 billion years after the Big Bang. The study reveals a complex structure and suggests that the galaxy formed through a major, gas-rich merger.

title: The Quasar SDSS J153636.22+044127.0: A Double-Peaked Emitter in a Candidate Binary Black-Hole System
summary: This paper investigates the quasar SDSS J153636.22+044127.0, which exhibits double-peaked emission lines and is proposed to be a binary black hole system. The authors use a circular Keplerian disk model to fit the Hα and Hβ profiles, finding that the system is consistent with being both a double-peaked emitter and a binary black hole system.

title: Hydrogen molecular ions for improved determination of fundamental constants
summary: This paper proposes a new route towards an independent determination of the Rydberg constant, nuclear radii and nucleus-to-electron mass ratios using high-resolution laser spectroscopy of hydrogen molecular ions. The method relies on Doppler-free two-photon transitions in ensembles of trapped and sympathetically cooled HMI, allowing for improved accuracy by several orders of magnitude.

title: Chiral violations from one-loop domain wall fermions
summary: This paper studies chiral symmetry breaking in domain-wall fermions using lattice perturbation theory. The authors calculate the residual mass and other matrix elements measuring the breaking of chiral symmetry, and find that the truncation of domain-wall fermions at finite N s generates a nonvanishing residual mass already at the tree level.

title: Light-mass Bragg cavity polaritons in planar quantum dot lattices
summary: This paper investigates the exciton-polariton modes of a quantum dot lattice embedded in a planar optical cavity, focusing on Bragg polariton modes obtained by tuning the exciton and the cavity modes into resonance at high symmetry points of the Brillouin Zone. The authors exploit the newly gained opportunity of growing artificial structures with spatial periodicity comparable to the wavelength of the confined quasiparticle, the exciton in their case.

title: Ultralight Dark Matter Detection with Mechanical Quantum Sensors
summary: This paper explores the use of mechanical quantum sensors to detect ultralight dark matter candidates. The authors propose an array of sensors as a scalable and sensitive detection method, leveraging the high force sensitivities and rapid scalability in mass of these devices.

title: The Discovery of Herbig-Haro Objects in LDN 673
summary: This paper reports the discovery of twelve faint Herbig-Haro objects in the region of LDN 673 using a novel color-composite imaging method. The research focuses on understanding star formation in the Aquila clouds, but does not involve any machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.

title: Terahertz Imaging Progress at Capital Normal University
summary: This paper presents the progress on terahertz imaging technology at Capital Normal University, focusing on active and passive imaging methods. The research aims to improve imaging speed and resolution for non-destructive testing and security inspection applications.

title: The mass of the Delta resonance in a finite volume: fourth-order calculation
summary: This paper calculates the self-energy of the Delta (1232) resonance in a finite volume using chiral effective field theory with explicit spin-3/2 fields. The calculations are performed up-to-and-including fourth order in the small scale expansion and yield an explicit parameterization of the energy spectrum of the interacting pion-nucleon pair in a finite box in terms of both the quark mass and the box size L.

title: Quantum-Electrodynamical Time-Dependent Density Functional Theory. I. A Gaussian Atomic Basis Implementation
summary: This paper presents a quantum-electrodynamical time-dependent density functional theory (QED-TDDFT) implementation using a Gaussian atomic basis. The authors examine the effects of dipole self-energy, rotating wave approximation, and Tamm-Dancoff approximation on QED-TDDFT eigenstates in an optical cavity.

title: Dynamics of collisional mountain ranges: a progress report on the Alps
summary: This paper presents a collection of research papers on the geology of the Alps, focusing on topics such as mountain building, crustal differentiation, and tectonic activity. The papers use traditional geological methods and do not involve machine learning or artificial intelligence.

title: Restrictions on Some Western Songs: a Counter Hegemony Effort by the West Java Regional Indonesian Broadcasting Commission
summary: This paper analyzes the restriction on broadcasting 17 western songs in Indonesia from a counter hegemony perspective. The study examines how the West Java Regional Indonesian Broadcasting Commission's decision to restrict the songs is perceived by the public and industry players, highlighting the tension between resistance to western music hegemony and the failure of counter hegemony efforts.

title: Contributing Factors in Whether Displaced Households Want to Receive Humanitarian Information from Humanitarian Actors: Iraq Multi-Cluster Needs Assessment
summary: This paper investigates the factors related to displaced households' desire for humanitarian information in Iraq. The study uses data from the eighth round of the Iraq Multi-Cluster Needs Assessment and identifies significant differences between internally displaced person (IDP) and returnee households in terms of interest in receiving humanitarian information. The research highlights the need for new strategies, such as using online or mobile communication to provide humanitarian information to vulnerable groups.
statisticalMethods: Rao-Scott corrected chi-squared analyses for categorical data and design-weighted univariable linear regression for numerical data

title: Infrastructuring Public Consultation in Town Planning— How Town Planners Translate Public Consultation into a Socio-Technical Support System
summary: This paper examines the role of town planners in translating public consultation requirements into socio-technical arrangements for supporting public consultations. The study uses an infrastructure approach to understand how planners' work with technology is realized within and through institutional factors, highlighting the importance of considering both social and technical aspects of infrastructures.

title: Reforming the U.S. Stockholding and voting systems
summary: This paper examines the inefficiencies in the US stockholding system, which has led to voting pathologies. The authors propose using blockchain technology to enable the tracing of share ownership and mitigate these issues.

title: Certificates of Confidentiality and Unexpected Complications for Pragmatic Clinical Trials
summary: This paper examines the implications of the new Certificate of Confidentiality (CoC) policy on pragmatic clinical trials. The authors identify three issues related to CoCs that are problematic for PCTs: incomplete protections for sensitive data in electronic health records, requirements for notifying subjects about CoCs, and the need for formal guidance from the NIH.

title: Is There Material Liability of Workers and Employees as a Type of Legal Liability in Contemporary Russian Law and Legislation?
summary: This paper examines the concept of material liability in contemporary Russian law and legislation, specifically focusing on its application to workers and employees. The authors discuss various perspectives on material liability, including its relationship with civil liability and its role in labor law.

title: LIMITING PRESIDENTIAL TERM OF OFFICE IN INDONESIA: A DEMOCRATIC PERSPECTIVE
summary: This paper examines the limitation of presidential term of office in Indonesia from a democratic perspective. The authors argue that the model of presidential period limitation for at maximum two periods must be carried out by adding the length of service to more than five years and requiring an interlude between the first and the second period. However, they also note that this provision was influenced by the US presidential government system and may conflict with democracy principles.

title: Migration Fears in the United States and the Geopolitical Risk Index
summary: This study examines the relationship between migration fears in the U.S. and geopolitical risk, finding that increased migration fears lead to higher levels of geopolitical risk. The research uses a publicly available measure of migration fears and a barometer of concern about possible disruptions to peace in international relations.

title: Terms of Copyright Protection and Inappropriate Rules in the Law on Intellectual Property for Current Folklore Works in Vietnam
summary: This paper analyzes the existing laws of Vietnam regarding copyright protection for folklore works, highlighting contradictions and unclear provisions. The author argues that current legal frameworks do not guarantee consistency, concreteness, and clarity in protecting copyright and related rights.

title: Clientelism and Vote Buying in Low-Cost Housing Provision: A Case Study of the Greater Giyani Local Municipality
summary: This paper examines clientelism and vote buying in low-cost housing provision, focusing on the Greater Giyani Local Municipality. The authors argue that despite constitutional ambitions, the ruling African National Congress (ANC) utilizes low-cost houses for clientelistic and vote-buying propensities. No machine learning or artificial intelligence methods are used in this study.

title: Towards the real-time inclusion of sex- and age-disaggregated data in pandemic responses
summary: This paper emphasizes the importance of incorporating sex- and age-disaggregated data into pandemic responses, highlighting the need for gender-sensitive approaches to public health. Despite existing commitments and tools, the lack of continuous monitoring of such data limits the effectiveness of responses.

title: Using health impact assessment (HIA) to understand the wider health and well-being implications of policy decisions: the COVID-19 ‘staying at home and social distancing policy’ in Wales
summary: This paper examines the use of Health Impact Assessment (HIA) to understand the wider health and well-being implications of policy decisions, specifically in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic in Wales. The authors highlight the importance of HIA as a decision-informing tool that can identify potential positive or negative impacts on individual and population health and well-being.

title: Techno-sovereignism: the political rationality of contemporary Italian populism
summary: This paper explores the governmentality of the Yellow-Green coalition in Italy, analyzing how it combined right-wing and techno-populist elements to exert power. The analysis reveals that technology emerges with normative, affective, and aesthetic dimensions integral to a way of apprehending and rationalizing the social world.

title: Power dynamics and health initiative design as determinants of peacebuilding: a case study of the Syrian conflict
summary: This paper examines the role of power dynamics and health initiative design in determining peacebuilding outcomes in the Syrian conflict. The authors use a case study approach to analyze healthcare initiatives at three levels of the power structure, finding that community-level initiatives have greater peacebuilding potential due to their smaller budgets, reliance on local organizations, and distributed credit across stakeholders.

title: Quality and Tourism Supply: A Study of Enterprises Linked to Rural Community-Based Tourism in the Canton of Riobamba
summary: This paper examines the quality and supply of community-based tourism in rural parishes of Ecuador, focusing on the role of local communities in developing sustainable tourism practices. The study uses a qualitative-interpretative method to analyze the characteristics of community tourism services and their impact on local development.

title: The “General Close of Military Operations” as the Benchmark for the Declassification of Armed Conflicts and the End of the Applicability of International Humanitarian Law
summary: This paper examines the concept of the 'general close of military operations' as a benchmark for determining the end of armed conflicts and the applicability of international humanitarian law. The authors argue that this notion is essential in declassifying situations of armed conflict, but it has been underutilized in legal discussions.

title: Soft Law in International Investment Law and Arbitration
summary: This paper examines the role of soft law in international investment law and arbitration, exploring its impact on the formation of binding international law. The authors assess whether and to what extent soft law has entered into international investment law and adjudication, considering its content, aim, and role in procedural and substantive issues.

title: Closing gaps, opening doors: an experimental collaboration in stem cell intervention
summary: This paper discusses the regulation of stem cell treatments and the need for a Canadian Stem Cell Database to track patient outcomes. The authors propose a collaborative approach between stakeholders, including researchers, clinicians, ethicists, entrepreneurs, government, and other stakeholders, to establish a database that can provide valuable insights into the efficacy and safety of stem cell interventions.

title: Polarization: What Do We Know and What Can We Do About It?
summary: This paper examines the consequences and causes of polarization in Europe, proposing potential remedies to combat it. The authors use an aggregate, longitudinal unique dataset containing 47 European countries across more than 170 years from 1848 to 2020. They find that polarization has been on the rise since the 1960s, with a significant increase in the last decade. The paper highlights the negative consequences of polarization for democracy and proposes solutions to address it.

title: The Transparency Paradox: Why Transparency Alone will not Improve Campaign Regulations
summary: This paper examines the role of transparency in improving campaign regulations, arguing that while transparency may help quell instances of malfeasance, it can also increase citizen distrust in democratic processes. The author uses a case study of the Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act 2000 to demonstrate how transparency mechanisms can be implemented to better support legislative aims.

title: Denying the Animosity: Understanding Narratives of Harmony from the Nellie Massacre, 1983
summary: This paper examines how societies in India adhere to a narrative of harmony between different communities and a familial structure before a conflict breaks out, using oral narratives from the Nellie Massacre of 1983. The research finds that despite underlying problems, nations and ethnic communities imagine themselves as a family, which may contribute to genocide denial.

title: The historical roots of the creation of the Catalan private-public hospital model: c. 1870-1935
summary: This paper analyzes the historical creation of the hospital system in Catalonia, focusing on the numerical preponderance of privately owned hospitals and beds over those of public provision. The study reinterprets the keys that shaped this historical model during a strategic period (1870-1935) using new statistical and documentary sources.

title: Religious Leaders in Politics: Rio de Janeiro Under the Mayor-Bishop in the Times of the Pandemic
summary: This paper examines the intersection of religion and politics through the lens of Bishop Marcelo Crivella's leadership in Rio de Janeiro during the COVID-19 pandemic. The authors analyze how Crivella's policies combine religious and political elements, strengthening the church's influence and authority.

title: The Resettlement Experiences of Oromo Women Who Entered Canada as Refugees
summary: This paper explores the resettlement experiences of Oromo women who immigrated to Canada as refugees, highlighting the ongoing roles that gender plays in their everyday struggles. The study uses a qualitative, intersectional approach to examine the emigration journey and its impact on refugee women's lives.

title: Generation Y’s Information Needs Concerning Sharing Rides in Autonomous Mobility on Demand Systems
summary: This paper examines the effect of providing information about fellow passengers on the willingness to share rides in shared autonomous mobility-on-demand systems. The study finds that detailed information about fellow travelers reduces compensation demands, but male gender information increases refusal rates.

title: The role of spatial, verbal, numerical, and general reasoning abilities in complex word problem solving for young female and male adults
summary: This study analyzed the relative importance of different cognitive abilities for solving complex mathematical word problems, finding that spatial ability, verbal ability, numerical ability, and general reasoning all play a significant role. The results suggest that CWP solving requires a broad facet of cognitive abilities beyond mere mathematical competencies.

title: Correlation between Depression Symptoms and Sleep Variables during COVID-19 Pandemic
summary: This paper investigates the correlation between depression symptoms and sleep variables in Brazilians facing pandemic-associated stressors. The study found significant positive correlations between depression symptoms and sleep quality, latency, and sleepiness, but not with sleep time. The results suggest that individuals with high depression symptoms may struggle to stay awake or alert, and that adequate sleep is crucial for attenuating brain inflammation.
statisticalMethods: Spearman approach, Kruskal-Wallis analysis, Dunn post hoc test

title: Conners 3-Parent (Short): Measurement Invariance Across Gender, Concurrent and Discriminant Validities
summary: This study examines measurement invariance across gender for the Conners 3-Parent (Short) scale, a measure used to diagnose Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder and other disorders. The authors use confirmatory factor analysis to test for configural, metric, scalar, and error variances invariance, finding support for full measurement invariance and equivalencies of latent mean scores across gender.

title: Remaining Human in COVID-19: Dialogues on Psychogeography
summary: This paper explores the impact of COVID-19 on human identity and relationships, using a posthumanist perspective to consider the role of microorganisms in shaping our lives. The authors argue that the pandemic has disrupted traditional notions of human-animal relations and highlights the interconnectedness of humans, animals, and microorganisms.

title: Understanding Moral Injury Morbidity: A Qualitative Study Examining Chaplain’s Perspectives
summary: This qualitative study examines the perspectives of chaplains on moral injury in veterans, highlighting its impact on social functioning and suicide risk. The research finds that moral injury presents as 'spiritual pain' and/or 'crises of faith', leading to self-isolation, withdrawal, and increased thoughts of suicide.

title: Hidden in Plain View
summary: This paper focuses on the challenges of recruiting and retaining marginalized young people in research, particularly in longitudinal studies. The authors develop five principles to guide sampling, recruitment, and retention efforts, which aim to create facilitative environments that encourage active engagement from these youth.

title: Cultural Adaptation of the Preschool Anxiety Scale in Romania
summary: This paper presents a cultural adaptation of the Preschool Anxiety Scale (PAS) for Romanian preschool children. The study investigates the psychometric properties of the PAS in Romania and its cross-cultural replicability. The results show that the PAS has satisfactory psychometric properties on the Romanian sample, with good reliability and fit to the underlying correlated five-factor structural model.

title: Elevated Gestational IL-13 During Fetal Development Is Associated With Hyperactivity and Inattention in Eight-Year-Old Children
summary: This study investigates the association between maternal immune activation during fetal development and behavioral outcomes in children. Elevated gestational IL-13 concentrations were found to increase the risk for children to develop hyperactive/inattentive behavior, with no effect observed from maternal atopic dermatitis. The study highlights the importance of considering both maternal cytokines and polyunsaturated fatty acids in understanding neurobehavioral sequelae in offspring.
statisticalMethods: The study used adjusted odds ratios (OR) and marginal risks (MR) to quantify the associations between gestational cytokines, PUFA-containing lipids, and behavioral difficulties in children.

title: An evaluation of the psychometric properties of the sf-12v2 health survey among adults with hemophilia
summary: This study evaluates the psychometric properties of the SF-12v2 health survey among adults with hemophilia. The research focuses on assessing the validity and reliability of the SF-12v2 in this specific population, which is essential for making informed treatment decisions. However, machine learning or artificial intelligence methods are not used in this paper.

title: Prevalence of Mental Health Complaints Among Performing Arts Students Is Associated With COVID-19 Preventive Measures
summary: This study investigates the effect of COVID-19 preventive measures on the mental health of performing arts students. The research found that the prevalence of mental health complaints increased during the lockdown, with 75.5% of participants experiencing moderate to very severe loneliness.
statisticalMethods: Chi-square tests, repeated-measures ANOVA with deviation contrasts, visual analogue scale (VAS), single-item sleep quality rating scale

title: The association of PTSD symptom severity with amygdala nuclei volumes in traumatized youths
summary: This paper investigates the relationship between post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptom severity and amygdala nuclei volumes in traumatized youths. The study found that increased PTSD symptom severity was associated with volumetric reductions of all basolateral as well as central and medial nuclei, but not with longitudinal symptom development.

title: Psychological Impact of COVID-19 Outbreak on Families of Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder and Typically Developing Peers: An Online Survey
summary: This study examines the psychological impact of COVID-19 on families of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and typically developing peers. The research focuses on parental distress, children's emotional responses, and adaptive behaviors during periods of mandatory lockdown. Although machine learning or artificial intelligence methods are not used in this paper, it explores the interplay between parental distress, children's emotional responses, and adaptive behaviors in children with autism during periods of mandatory lockdown.

title: Responding to Social Distancing in Conducting Stakeholder Workshops in COVID-19 Era
summary: This paper explores how social science research, specifically stakeholder engagement using the Deliberative Multicriteria Evaluation (DMCE) method, can be adapted to take place in a virtually distant society. The authors successfully transferred their workshops online using familiar platforms and video conferencing tools, demonstrating that stakeholder engagement can continue despite social distancing measures.

title: The Effect of Consistency on Short-Term Memory for Scenes
summary: This paper investigates the role of consistency in scene short-term memory, examining how changes in scene consistency affect change detection. The study suggests that consistent scenes facilitate visual short-term memory, but inconsistent scenes also have an advantage in capturing initial attention.

title: Bouncing back from the pandemic? A psychosocial analysis of older adults in urban areas of Malaysia
summary: This paper investigates the psychosocial impact of COVID-19 on older adult populations in Malaysian cities, focusing on behavioral changes, anxiety, and adaptation. The study found that despite social distancing measures, participants' adaptive responses reduced the psychosocial impact of the pandemic.

title: Putting your best face forward: How instructor emoji use influences students’ impressions of credibility, immediacy, and liking
summary: This study examines the impact of instructor emoji use on students' impressions of credibility, immediacy, and liking in technologically-mediated out-of-class communication. The research finds that instructors' emoji use can influence students' perceptions, but the meaning of emojis is context-dependent and may not always be suited to the message.

title: Improved Neural Control of Movements Manifests in Expertise-Related Differences in Force Output and Brain Network Dynamics
summary: This study investigates expertise-related changes in fine motor control, specifically examining the neural control of movements in experts compared to novices. The research uses a dynamic force control task and electrophysiological data to analyze brain network dynamics, finding that experts exhibit more precise, less variable, and more complex force output, as well as increased neural efficiency.

title: A structural equation model of falls at home in individuals with chronic stroke, based on the international classification of function, disability, and health
summary: This paper uses a structural equation model to explain falls at home in individuals with chronic stroke based on the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health. The study found that contextual factors are the strongest association with falls at home, and activity limitations presented by balance ability are directed to falls at home.

title: Effects of sleep on positive, negative and neutral valenced story and image memory
summary: This study investigates the effects of sleep on memory consolidation for stories and images with different emotional valences. The results show that sleep enhances recall performance for both story and image memory, particularly for emotionally valenced stimuli.

title: Behind the Reasons: The Relationship Between Adolescent and Young Adult Mental Health Risk Factors and Exposure to Season One of Netflix’s 13 Reasons Why
summary: This paper examines the relationship between adolescent and young adult mental health risk factors and exposure to season one of Netflix's 13 Reasons Why. The study uses a survey of 1,100 adolescents and young adults in the United States to investigate how individual-level variables relate to participants' viewing decisions. The results suggest that youth make intentional decisions about mental health-related media use based on their personal characteristics.

title: Death anxiety, exposure to death, mortuary preferences, and religiosity in five countries
summary: This paper presents three datasets from a project examining the relationship between death anxiety and religiosity across five countries. The study uses survey data to investigate how exposure to death, mortuary preferences, and religiosity are related to death anxiety. While machine learning or AI methods are not used in this research, it provides valuable insights into cross-cultural differences in attitudes towards death and dying.

title: Item-Specificity and Intention in Episodic Memory
summary: This paper presents the PEP model, which accurately reflects task switching based on bottom-up assumptions and episodic memory. The model's ability to reconcile two theoretical accounts of long-term stimulus-response bindings is a significant contribution in the field of psychology.

title: The relationships between cognitive function, literacy and HIV status knowledge among older adults in rural South Africa
summary: This paper examines the relationship between cognitive function, literacy, and HIV status knowledge among older adults in a rural South African community. The authors use data from a population-based study to assess the associations among cognition, literacy, and HIV status knowledge, and determine how much of the relationship between education and knowledge of HIV status is accounted for by cognitive function and literacy.

title: Hablo Inglés y Español: Cultural Self-Schemas as a Function of Language
summary: This study examines the effect of language on self-schemas in Mexican-American bilinguals. The researchers used an open-ended approach to collect data, allowing participants to describe their personality in both English and Spanish. The results show that language primed bilinguals to think about different self-schemas, with Mexican self-schemas being more salient in Spanish and U.S. American self-schemas being more salient in English.
